pageTitle: Only Connect - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {21349=On 1 March 2010, an interactive online version of this round was put on the Only Connect website.[2] Since mid-2011, coinciding with series 5, the website took online submissions for new Connecting Walls, although a successful submission does not guarantee publication on the site.[citation needed] The online game was discontinued for series 10., 3592=Only Connect is a British quiz show that aired on BBC Four from 15 September 2008 to 7 July 2014 and then moved to BBC Two from 1 September 2014 and is presented by Victoria Coren Mitchell. In the series, teams compete in a tournament of finding connections between seemingly unrelated clues., 8172=The phrase "Only connect" was originally used as the epigraph to E. M. Forster's 1910 novel Howards End. It was spoken by the character Margaret Schlegel.}
textBeforeTable: Series[edit] Transmissions[edit] Series 10: Orienteers (Paul Beecher, Sean Blanchflower, Simon Spiro) Series 9: Europhiles (Douglas Thomson, Mark Seager, Khuram Rashid) Series 8: Board Gamers (Hywel Carver, Jamie Karran, Michael Wallace) Series 7: Francophiles (Ian Clark, Mark Walton, Sam Goodyear) Series 6: Scribes (Holly Pattenden, Dom Tait, Gareth Price) Series 5: Analysts (Paul Steeples, David Lea, William De Ath) Series 4: Epicureans (David Brewis, Katie Bramall-Stainer, Aaron Bell) Series 3: Gamblers (Jenny Ryan, Dave Bill, Alan Gibbs) Series 2: Rugby Boys (Richard Parnell, Gary Dermody, Mark Labbett) Series 1: Crossworders (Mark Grant, David Stainer, Ian Bayley) Champions[edit] The round lasts for between 90 seconds and three minutes. The team with the most points at the end of the game is the winner. If teams are tied, then a single sudden-death puzzle is given to the captains of each team. If a captain buzzes in first and gives the correct answer then their team wins, but an incorrect answer automatically forfeits the game. Although no category is officially given they make reference to their own role as sudden-death questions. Examples are "So Long and Thanks for All the Fish", "To the Victor, the Spoils" and "Winner Stays On". Teams answer simultaneously using buzzers, and score 1 point for each puzzle they solve.
